awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase II:  SSD In-Situ Processing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project will be to fundamentally change what a storage device can do, and give storage a third capability that is not addressed by existing storage technology - the ability to actually process user data.  For the computation to take place, only the computational request and the resulting data need to transfer over the storage interface, reducing interface traffic and the required power. The advent of Big Data and the increasing use of Hyperscale Server technology have resulted in the creation of an additional storage tier that is different from traditional enterprise storage. This new tier requires significantly larger capacity yet lower cost, lower operating power, and yet must still exhibit enterprise level reliability. This combination of characteristics cannot be serviced by existing technologies, and execution with large data sets typical of Big Data results in inefficient solutions. The information being stored represents the large, unstructured data mined by today's companies for key information and trends that help dictate corporate direction, advertising, and monetization. Future applications include machine learning for video analytics, genome sequencing and enabling Fog Storage and Fog Computing, among others.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase II project explores the Big Data paradigm shift where processing capability is pushed as close to the data as possible. The In-Situ processing technology pushes this concept to the absolute limit, by putting the computational capability directly into the storage itself and eliminating the need to move data to main memory before processing. The technology innovation begins with a solid foundation of an enterprise SSD tailored for the needs of modern Data Centers. Key technology that will be added to support these capabilities include hardware-assisted quality of service control, low-cost 3D-TLC and QLC NAND Flash enablement through the use of advanced ECC, and a proprietary elastic Flash Translation Layer to support extremely large capacity drives. The final element added to this foundation will be the ability to perform computation directly on the data with the addition of specialized In-Situ processing aided by hardware accelerators.

por.por_cntn:
NGD is revolutionizing the edge and distributed cloud with its unique Computational Storage technology that enables in-storage near-data processing by implementing the fundamental concept of moving compute to data. The democratization of data in a data driven world calls for complex applications to extract valuable information ranging from search and indexing to databases, security and machine learning for computer vision to name a few. NGD has introduced an NVMe based solid state drive (SSD) utilizing its own fully integrated computational storage controller which is manufactured on a 14nm advanced node technology to address these needs.

During Phases II and IIB of this project NGD Systems has engineered and began commercializing high capacity Computational Storage devices based on a controller ASIC powered by a general-purpose, quad-core 64-bit application processor and four SIMD co-processors. To the best of our knowledge, Newport is the first commodity SSD that can be configured to run a server-like operating system (e.g., Linux). This enables software application developers to fully leverage high-level programming languages, existing tools and libraries to minimize coding and maintenance effort as well as unlocking the power of container technology and container management platforms to deploy in-storage applications in the field. Newport can be dynamically configured to be used as either a general solid state drive or a full-blown computational storage drive capable of processing data in-situ. We have demonstrated that not only the technology is fully functional and ready for commercialization, but it also augments the performance and increases the energy efficiency of computing and storage systems across a large spectrum of applications and uses cases.

 

Intellectual Merit:

In the age of Big Data, the massive volume of data produced every day is posing a significant challenge of extracting useful information and knowledge from the data in a timely and efficient way.

In the traditional Von Neumann architecture that has been in use for the last 70 years, storage devices are simply used to store data. The data has to be read first, and then transferred to host before being processed. This SBIR project allowed us to develop Computational Storage, an emerging technology that places computing capabilities directly on storage (i.e., in-storage processing) and enables the data to be processed in the place where it resides. By bringing intelligence to the storage media itself, data reduction and qualification can occur before the data is sent to the host, resulting in the system's overall throughput being increased. In addition to facilitating faster processing, this also enables the host processing resources to be better utilized and to scale across a larger number of workloads -- thus cutting costs for the enterprise. Cost efficiencies are further increased through a reduced-power envelope, as well as through reduced demand for server memory and network bandwidth resources. Computational Storage adds to existing heterogeneous computing and near-data processing technologies to address the needs of cloud and edge markets.

 

Broader Impact:

Computational Storage is defined as architectures that provide Computational Storage Services coupled to storage, offloading host processing, or reducing data movement.  It incorporates aspects of heterogeneous computing and near-data processing technologies. Computational Storage architectures enable improvements in application performance and/or infrastructure efficiency through the integration of compute resources: directly with storage, near the storage or between the host and the storage. These compute resources are outside of the traditional compute and memory architecture. The goal of these architectures is to: enable parallel computation; reduce I/O traffic; and/or to alleviate other constraints on existing compute, memory, storage, and I/O. The trend in computing towards data-intensive applications is clear, and the efficient storage and handling of large amount of data have become extremely important. Increased amount of data led to I/O contention and high-performance interfaces, and the cost of moving data between storage and processing units has grown significantly so that the conventional paradigm of passive storage can no longer handle large amount of data efficiently. Computational Storage is a scalable solution to the problem that can significantly reduce the amount of data moved between storage and processing units.
